speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, on March 18, 1992,1 asked the Minister of National Health and Welfare to review decisions made by an unqualified official in his department, Mr. Greg Smith. These decisions legally and medically affect three thalidomide victims in my constituency, Darcy Petkau, Mrs. Cheryl Wood and Laurel Webb. The minister's response in the
House to my question was irresponsible and arrogant. He simply said no.
I would like to remind the minister that on February 13,1990, when this program was announced in the House by the Minister of National Health and Welfare the minister said: "This program would be on the basis of compassion and understanding and not liability". As well, he went on to say: "I would like to assure everyone in the country that the funding I am announcing today is over and above the settlements the victims received from the manufacturer of thalidomide".
He also indicated that the government estimated that there were only 75 to 100 people living in Canada who were affected.
I dispute his numbers because I was practising medicine at that time and I know how many people were prescribed thalidomide at that time. Basically what the current minister is now saying is that the victims must either have been on the original list which the department compiled in 1963, or have received a settlement from a drug company.
There are many additional victims who can and are producing legal medical records as proof, like my three constituents, for their eligibility for the program. However, the minister and his departmental staff are stonewalling.
I would like to quote a letter from one of those constituents, a letter written by Dr. Boyar on October 18, 1991, to Mr. Greg Smith, Director, Extraordinary Assistance Plan, here in Ottawa:
Dear Mr. Smith:
This is to confirm that I did deliver the above patient on 07 May 1962 while still in general practice. His birth defect is a classical thalidomide defect involving his left hand. This has been recently documented for you by Dr. Fowlow, plastic surgeon.
The doctor admits that he had prescribed thalidomide to the mother during her pregnancy.
Another medical record is that for Cheryl Wood and it is from the Shriners Hospital for Crippled Children, dated June 16, 1965. It says:
Deformity of the left forearm and left hand, duration since birth. The mother was extremely sick during the early part of the pregnancy and used thalidomide tablets.
This is medical and legal proof that those people had been prescribed thalidomide.

March 30, 1992
Adjournment Debate
I believe there is a tragic injustice being committed by the department of health and welfare and the minister. The minister refuses to take his ministerial responsibilities seriously. I ask him to be fair and honest and if he cannot be that way, he should resign.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Reid (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in June of last year the final arrangements were made for an extraordinary assistance plan for Canadian thalidomide victims and I am pleased to put before the House information on the implementation of that plan since that time.
The plan provides initially for $4.5 million to be divided equally among all eligible recipients and another $4 million to be paid on the basis of placement into one of three disability categories.
To this date 105 individuals have been confirmed to be eligible and the government has made payments to 101 of those for a total of $42,400 per person.
Medical evaluations to determine the level of disability category have been progressing well. Two-thirds of the evaluations have been completed and the rest are to be completed by the end of April. At that time payments will be calculated and paid to the recipients.
Sadly not all those who applied to the plan could be confirmed as thalidomide victims but the criteria for the program are clear. There must be proof of maternal consumption of Kevadon or Thlimol, the two brands of the drug available in Canada at that time during the first trimester of pregnancy. There is no other means to determine whether someone is a thalidomide victim.
There are a number of ways of attesting to whether that is-Mr. Speaker, are you allowing me to conclude or telling me to conclude?

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: I am allowing you to conclude.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
Thank you, Mr. Speaker, I will be quick.
Anyone who received a settlement from the drug company already proved the question of maternal consumption of thalidomide in that context. Others were identified, as my colleague has said, during a major national research study in 1962-63.
The government has also taken steps to provide non-monetary support, providing up to $1 million in funding for services needed by thalidomide victims.
In summary, the extraordinary assistance plan is a significant response to Canadian thalidomide victims, and the delivery of the plan to eligible Canadians is progressing well.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, natural gas is a vital part of the economy of my province as well as Canada's energy future. The region enjoys a large surplus of natural gas reserves which has allowed us to extract this very clean burning fossil fuel for export. More gas projects are under way and there has been very heavy competition between two pipeline consortia for rights to build a new export pipeline out of Alberta to the southwestern U.S.
Natural gas exporters from our province have been fair in their trading activities with our friends to the south beginning last year. However we saw that these exporters had to deal with certain regulators in the state of California who were not interested in playing fair. To put it bluntly those regulators, the California Public Utilities Commission, chose to take advantage of our suppliers by blackmailing them for shorter term supply contracts.
In late November of last year those regulators ordered the largest utility in northern California, Pacific Gas and Electric, to dump its long-term contracts with western Canadian gas producers.
It is a clear violation of article 905 of the free trade agreement. I rose therefore in this House on December 5, 1991 to ask the minister of energy if he agreed. He spoke of joint press conferences, consultations with western provincial energy ministers and consultations with the U.S., but he would not give a simple undertaking to support the claims of our suppliers.
The question was simple: would the minister lend support to groups such as the Independent Petroleum Association of Canada? A review of the matter was held in front of the National Energy Board. Speaking personally I hoped that this issue would transcend partisan cleavages between the minister and myself. I was mistaken, because when the minister rose to answer the supplementary question he said that he could not even bring himself to speak to the question.
March 30, 1992

He said in the House at the time:
I mean I don't know where this guy is, except that he just wants to make a point in the House.
That is a former teacher talking. It was very confusing. Why else would one want to speak in the House if one did not want to make a point? The minister obviously believes that any member who rises in the House and does not sing the praises of the government is some type of an obstructionist nuisance.
The interventions in this dispute over natural gas are based on a sincere desire to see it resolved as quickly as possible. I hoped that desire might converge with that of the minister of energy. If it did, I hoped that our converging desires would have an impact on the California Public Utilities Commission, but it seems that this government, as in so many other issues, would rather see our natural gas industry twist in the wind as far as its most profitable export market is concerned than actually presenting a united front in opposition to those moves in California.
I had written to the governor of California on the matter in mid-December. A reply has not been received, but since the letter was sent 190 western Canadian gas producers and distributors are no closer to receiving fair treatment from the California Public Utilities Commission. The action of the commission has had the effect of exerting downward pressure on the already depressed price of natural gas. Furthermore, in an age of deregulation its demands that California utilities purchase only short-term contracts has the effect of distorting fundamental conditions in the marketplace.
Our Natural Energy Board has made a good attempt in trying to mediate and resolve this state of affairs. Unfortunately the NEB has no regulatory authority over the actions of the California commission.
It would seem to any reasonable person, I suggest, that the consultative mechanism for energy matters in article 905 of the free trade agreement will have to be used. Unfortunately the government has yet to inform the House whether it has chosen to use this option to resolve the dispute which puts into jeopardy several thousand jobs in Alberta and British Columbia. If it has, it has refused to inform the House about any progress in the consultation.
Adjournment Debate
I would therefore ask the parliamentary secretary or some parliamentary secretary, to rise in the House and deal intelligently with the question.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Belsher (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in reply to the hon. member for Edmonton Southeast I would just like to review some of the facts.
In December 1991 the Governments of Canada, Alberta and British Columbia and the Canadian natural gas industry agreed on a three-party strategy to respond to the California Public Utilities Commission's capacity brokering decision.
First, it was decided that consultations should be initiated to convince the CPUC of the need to rely on commercial negotiations.
Second, regulatory options would be examined to maintain the integrity of the first export agreement until a commercial restructuring by the commercial parties was concluded.
Third, our options and remedies under the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement would be carefully examined.
That consultative process commenced immediately and the representatives from the governments of Alberta and British Columbia and staff from the California Public Utilities Commission were invited to attend the regularly scheduled Energy Consultative Mechanism, the ECM-gas trade talks meeting between the Canadian and American federal government officials.
Discussions have continued under the umbrella of these special gas talks for the past few months with favourable results to date. It is important that we note that these discussions are intended to promote a regulatory environment that will facilitate a commercial solution. They are not intended to substitute for commercial negotiations.
In the interim the Canadian Petroleum Association, with the support of the Independent Petroleum Association of Canada, requested the National Energy Board to review the 1989 decision to extend the Alberta and Southern natural gas export licence. As a result, the board adopted interim measures to prevent the potential erosion of long-term contracted natural gas exports to northern California. These interim measures are subject

March 30, 1992
Adjournment Debate
to the outcome of the board's public hearings which are conducted in Calgary.
At this time I believe it is preferable to continue constructive dialogue with the CPUC as a means of resolving this dispute. The value of such a non-confrontational process should not be discounted. Nevertheless, should these talks not prove fruitful, we would still have at our disposal the ability to seek recourse under the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement.
I might add that I am cautiously optimistic that these talks will lead to a successful conclusion that will be mutually beneficial to the energy trading relationship and for it to continue in the future.

Mr. Speaker, I asked a question on the lobster fishery back on December 4, 1991 and my supplementary question was on quota. I want to deal with both of them.
At the time, I was asking the Minister of State for Transport, because of the opening of the season, and because of the crisis as far as price went in the lobster fishery, whether she would ensure that there would be cargo space available for York, which is a very lucrative market for the lobster fishermen from Nova Scotia and, for that matter, for other areas that ship their cargo of lobster to Europe.
At the time she said yes. It is now four months later and I have never heard back from the minister. Maybe tonight I will hear from the parliamentary secretary what will be done in the future in order to ensure, particularly when the season starts, that there is access to cargo.
Unfortunately, Mr. Speaker, the price back then was probably around $2.50; today it is a hefty $7.95 or $8-and-something. On the weekend it was said it might even go up as far as $10. If it is priced that way, the market is probably hard to fill at that price, but at the same time the number of lobsters has gone down.
The other question I raised at the time had to do with quotas, whether or not the groundfish would see an increase in quota for 1992.
At the time, that question was addressed to the parliamentary secretary. He is here in the House today and he answered: "I can tell the hon. member opposite yes, we will look into that immediately".
As a result, there were no increases for the sectors in groundfish. The only thing that has increased that I can see, and I think it is of grave concern, is the number of licences that have been issued for gill nets. I heard on the weekend that there are now 900 gill net licences in Scotia-Fundy, in one area. It is an incredible amount.
There will be a meeting on April 14 to see if these gill-netters can go to George's to set their gill nets on quota. A few years ago there was an over-capacity in one sector for groundfish and all of a sudden there are 900 licences that appear for gill-netting fish on the east coast. It is a real crisis.
If there are no fish and the boats are not able to fish, why the abundance of licences? Why are they going to George's Bank? When the UN has banned gill-nets, why is this government now opening up a gill-net fishery that never existed in the past in the ground fishery?
When you cannot find more quota there should not be this enlargement of activity that is going on out there. I wonder what the longliners think about all the gill-netters who will be fishing where they are. I think of the numbers that have been reduced in the dragger sector with all the gill-nets that are going to be there. I think of the poor stocks on George's Bank and in the Bay of Fundy that will be hurt because of loose gill-nets floating around the bottom and capturing the sea life there. Gill-nets are very harsh.
Perhaps the parliamentary secretary might want to bring that matter up. Since then, there has been no issue of additional quotas in the groundfish sector. But all of a sudden, there is an addition. When the quotas were announced in January, there were no additional quotas given, but there were these numbers of licences given.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Belsher (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member opposite is covering a wide range of subjects.
March 30, 1992

She asked about the amount of freight space on airlines going to Europe. The hon. member should remember that the government does not control any of the airlines that travel back and forth to Europe. It is not under the jurisdiction of the Department of Transport who set the regulations in place for how the airlines operate.
More particularly, with respect to the groundfish quotas for 1992 for the Scotia-Fundy region, the ground-fish plan on December 23 was released for the coming year. The total allowable catches for the Atlantic groundfish were set at the level scheduled within the multi-year groundfish plan which was introduced in 1991. The decisions announced for 1992 were based on the advice of CAFSAC, the Canadian Atlantic Fisheries Scientific Advisory Committee. They are also the product of consultations throughout the year with the fishermen's organizations, the industry and the provincial government.
The management measures introduced in 1991 for the 4VN winter cod fishery will continue to protect the juvenile cod and control dumping and the discarding of fish and enhance the data base for assessing the stock. Observer coverage, which had reached about 70 per cent
Adjournment Debate
the year before will be raised to 100 per cent and a program of observer-estimated catch will be mblished for 1992. As well, to alleviate the concern about the migration of the 4T cod to division 4VS, catches in the 4VS between January to April will be limited to 12,000 tonnes, based on the 4VS catch average of recent years.
For 1992 the fishermen will not be forced to transfer quotas. Under the current system transfers of fish are only acted upon after they have been requested by licence holders. At no time are fishermen requested to transfer quotas to companies.
The future of the Atlantic groundfish industry rests on responsible fisheries management. This means looking at the issues in a careful, open manner. It also means reconciling the needs of groups and communities for economic benefits today with the overriding duty to conserve and sustain the resource for future generations.
